1.words: Thank you everyone for joining us this morning. I'll have you guys do introductions in just a minute or two after I read the introduction that we have. So welcome to this conversation on Cortico's Local Voices Network sponsored by Education Action Forum of Maine and Educate Maine. There are three main purposes for this conversation. First, we want to create a way for Mainers to listen and learn about each other's experiences, values and perspectives, especially around education. Second, we want to gather voices from around the state to inform the direction of Maine's educational system. We have conversations for community members, educators, youth and people and in major Maine industries. Third, we want to create a unique listening channel through which we uplift the voices and the needs of the whole state, every county in order to build a healthier public sphere. And education of course is a critical part of that. To this end, we are inviting you to have a different type of conversation. These conversations are focused on sharing your personal stories from your lived experiences rather than beginning the conversation with our positions on issues. Following the conversation today, the video recording will be discarded and the audio will become part of the Local Voices Network collection. The data is owned by Education Action Forum of Maine and you will receive an email following this conversation, giving you access to the recording as well as all of the other recordings that have been part of this project. What you say will be publicly available but only publicly identifiable by how you introduce yourself. So please introduce yourself only with your first name and your role. Of course, you can introduce yourself with your last name if you want to, but typically we're asking people to do first name. And we have a little agreement to be recorded that I'm going to read. And after I read it, if you all agree, if you could say I agree, that would be great. As a participant in this conversation, you are providing consent to Education Action Forum of Maine and Educate Maine to use the recording in accordance with the mission of Maine ED 2050. The mission of Maine ED 2050 is to bring communities, educators, and youth together to discuss how education and schooling can be designed together for personal, civic and economic thriving in the next few decades. You also understand that the conversation will be part of a collection of Cortico's Local Voices Network, whose mission is to foster conversations in communities and in the media that improve or understanding of one another. Cortico will collect, retain, and analyze these conversations in keeping with that mission. If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

If you understand and agree to this, please say, I agree.

19.words: There's so many angles to approach that from of, I could argue that communication is a huge part of that. I think access to resources is our absolute bottom line for that. Access to resources so that we're not living in food insecurity, especially with Maine and Kennebec County specifically having such high levels of food insecurity that impacts every other area of someone's life. It's not just about feeling hungry. That's going to impact our young folks' ability to engage in education, that's going to then impact their future that impacts all of their physical development, their brain development. So something as seemingly simple as food, I feel like is what is a building block to getting that thriving, resilient community.

16.segment_words: I could argue that communication is a huge part of that. I think access to resources is our absolute bottom line for that. 20.words: Yeah. And I would just add... Excuse me, I apologize. Something actually learned from Kristel who is a great mentor for me. We all play a piece in this puzzle of creating a thriving, resilient community. And so I think a big piece of that is support, empathy, understanding that we are all human and we are all doing our best to try to better ourselves, better the environment we have for others. And so a big piece of our work lately has definitely been looking at strengths and the resources that we have around us, but also understanding that we're human and we're all trying to make it through. And so yeah, empathy, support, those are big pieces along with obviously food insecurity, making sure that people are being connected to shelter, food. It's hard to maintain your mental health when you aren't having those needs met.

29.words: I think one of the biggest pieces that I've seen as a shift has been away from the sad shock trauma approach to education and knowledge around mental health. For so long it was essentially scaring people out of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, scaring people out of being depressed and anxious. The wonderful advice that I think everyone is heard at some point, well have you tried just not worrying about it? Has always been the go-to fix for mental health. Whereas I feel like we've seen a time with a shift towards hope, health and strength, which has been something that's really important to our team in being able to have that shift in messaging because that's going to build that longer term resilience that's going to provide a whole lot more accessible messaging for our young people, honestly as well as adults because it's not othering the situation, it's instead inviting people in to have conversations around what's going well, how to grow, what's going well, and how it's okay for that to look different for every person.

28.segment_words: I think one of the biggest pieces that I've seen as a shift has been away from the sad shock trauma approach to education and knowledge around mental health.
28.linked_words: So our next question is reflecting on your time working in youth mental health, what are the ways in which working in this industry has changed and how have you been expected to grow, learn, or change?

30.words: From doing youth mental health first aid trainings in particular, we meet a lot of community members, teachers, individuals in and around the school. And a concept that came up in our trainings is adults, staff, teachers are so scared to say the wrong thing, they're not saying anything at all. And that's not a blame by any means. I just thought that was really impactful to hear, because mental health, there is such a stigma around it still that it can be really scary to approach these conversations. If you notice warning signs in a young person and you want to help them and not knowing exactly what to say. And so I think for me personally, what I've learned, what I've grown with is you can literally say, "Hey, I'm a support. I noticed some changes and I wanted to check in with you." I personally overcomplicate things and I'm not saying it's a simple topic by any means, but even though it's a scary conversation, being a support, being that trusted adult in someone's life is so much more important than saying the right thing. And so that was a really powerful thing for me to hear and to learn and kind of grow with. And working with young people directly. They want honest communication. I'm not saying treat them like adults because they're, they're young people, they're still learning, they're still growing, but being honest with them, "Hey, even though I'm an adult, I don't have all of the answers, but I want to help you. I want to be there for you." So this was a big learning point for me and an adjustment in making sure that I am providing the best support for young people while letting them know that, hey, again, we're human at the end of the day and we're going to do the best that we can do.

28.segment_words: I think for me personally, what I've learned, what I've grown with is you can literally say, "Hey, I'm a support. I noticed some changes and I wanted to check in with you." ... So this was a big learning point for me and an adjustment in making sure that I am providing the best support for young people while letting them know that, hey, again, we're human at the end of the day and we're going to do the best that we can do.

29.linked_words: For so long it was essentially scaring people out of suicidal thoughts and behaviors, scaring people out of being depressed and anxious. The wonderful advice that I think everyone is heard at some point, well have you tried just not worrying about it? Has always been the go-to fix for mental health. Whereas I feel like we've seen a time with a shift towards hope, health and strength, which has been something that's really important to our team in being able to have that shift in messaging because that's going to build that longer term resilience that's going to provide a whole lot more accessible messaging for our young people, honestly as well as adults because it's not othering the situation, it's instead inviting people in to have conversations around what's going well, how to grow, what's going well, and how it's okay for that to look different for every person.

31.words: For me as a person who is newer in the youth mental health professional field, I think I've been working in a time that has been perpetuated by change with the pandemic, that we are just experiencing constant change in how the field operates, how we're dealing with mental health. And I think I've been seeing a lot of positive changes in the fact that we're having a lot more open conversations. People are recognizing that mental health is a significant issue, whereas when I was a youth, not too, too long ago that those conversations were not happening. They were not encouraged, they were, it was that fear tactic. Have you tried not worrying about it? Very dismissive. So I've been seeing those changes happening over the years. And in particular, I think the pandemic has been a bit of a speed run of that.

29.segment_words: People are recognizing that mental health is a significant issue, whereas when I was a youth, not too, too long ago that those conversations were not happening. They were not encouraged, they were, it was that fear tactic. Have you tried not worrying about it? Very dismissive.

32.words: I would definitely agree with that. Thinking about the growth learning and changing definitely around that flexibility and willingness to adapt to the needs in the moment. I can't think of how many times that we have met with schools with a plan going in for a couple hour session with them on something and those plans getting completely derailed because we need to talk about self care with the adults because they might be approaching burnout at such a high rate that if we don't slow down and have that conversation, they're not going to hear and absorb any of the other content and information that we're going to be sharing with them. We can provide all of the awesome knowledge, resource, skills, abilities to folks, but if they're not in a space to hear it, to be able to internalize and reflect on that themselves, then it's gone in one ear out the other. And so being able to adjust and go with the flow a whole lot more than I feel like in the past has been needed. In terms of growing, something that I encountered when learning more about pronoun usage in conversation and introductions ongoing, is this concept of messing up gracefully. And that has just really resonated with me in all of the ways. So definitely comes out of the conversations and learning around pronouns, but it's something that I feel is important that we take and apply to all areas of our lives. There's such this focus on, as adults, we've got to do things right the first time. We've got to be perfect, knock it out, not have any struggles or problems or difficulties to overcome or overcome something. And instead by having that willingness to try something, try something we might fail at, commit and move forward until we learn that, hey, that wasn't the right way. That wasn't the right thing. But being able to be humble and secure enough in ourselves to be able to acknowledge that, hey, I said the wrong thing there. I'd like to make it right by doing X, Y, Z, I'm sorry, moving on. Taking ownership when we misspeak, when we misstep, when we don't act, when we should have acted. Again, acknowledging the human component to each of us, but also taking that responsibility within ourselves to speak up and to shine a light on that, to really normalize that none of us are operating at a hundred percent, none of us are perfect walking around and that's okay.

30.segment_words: I would definitely agree with that. Thinking about the growth learning and changing definitely around that flexibility and willingness to adapt to the needs in the moment.

I just thought that was really impactful to hear, because mental health, there is such a stigma around it still that it can be really scary to approach these conversations. If you notice warning signs in a young person and you want to help them and not knowing exactly what to say.

31.segment_words: I would definitely agree with that. Thinking about the growth learning and changing definitely around that flexibility and willingness to adapt to the needs in the moment.
31.linked_words: And in particular, I think the pandemic has been a bit of a speed run of that.

34.words: Absolutely. We spend a lot of time talking point blank about the necessity of we need to break down these walls that we have spent so many years building up, obviously always maintaining appropriate boundaries and professionalism. Of course, however, we need to stop projecting this image to our young people that some magical thing happens on your 18th birthday where you get imparted with all of the knowledge that you could ever possibly need. Because I don't know about you, hasn't happened for me just yet, maybe any day. But by showing that as adults, that we make mistakes that we're still learning, that we, are we sure of the next step, that can really build confidence for a young person because they don't feel like there's something wrong with them. They don't feel like they're not doing enough or knowing enough or good enough. Instead, they see that, that's a really normal part of life and that, that's worth talking about. It's not something you have to hide or be ashamed of.

Because I don't know about you, hasn't happened for me just yet, maybe any day. But by showing that as adults, that we make mistakes that we're still learning, that we, are we sure of the next step, that can really build confidence for a young person because they don't feel like there's something wrong with them. They don't feel like they're not doing enough or knowing enough or good enough. Instead, they see that, that's a really normal part of life and that, that's worth talking about. 36.words: And we're hoping that that piece will also be a support for adults as well, that they don't have to hold this, I'm perfect all of the time. And by no means are we saying that you should not be paying attention to warning signs and doing all of those things. We're saying, yes, do your job, do those things, but no one's perfect.

32.segment_words: that they don't have to hold this, I'm perfect all of the time.
32.linked_words: There's such this focus on, as adults, we've got to do things right the first time. We've got to be perfect, knock it out, not have any struggles or problems or difficulties to overcome or overcome something.

34.segment_words: And by no means are we saying that you should not be paying attention to warning signs and doing all of those things. We're saying, yes, do your job, do those things, but no one's perfect.
34.linked_words: we need to stop projecting this image to our young people that some magical thing happens on your 18th birthday where you get imparted with all of the knowledge that you could ever possibly need.

37.words: And that's another piece of why we encourage as many people as we can to engage in education around youth mental health. Because when we accept that I am not perfect as an individual, but hey, if I have all of the people around me are also keeping an eye, if they are also putting their knowledge and cognizance out there in the world that between the team of us, we're going to see a whole lot more. We're going to be able to be a better resource together than as one person that's trying to hold it together as the go-to for all in everything. Really encouraging that team approach, collectivism more so in the response to supporting our young people.

39.words: Yeah, thank you for adding that. Our next question is, what does success look like for you in relation to your work?

40.words: I think that can be a whole span of things. Some days it's thinking about what the statewide data is going to look like, that comes back measuring where young people's mental health is across the board. Sometimes the most awesome piece of success that we might see is having a session with young people on Zoom like we were doing over the pandemic and having a young person in a really rural community sending a direct message saying, "Wow, I didn't know that there were resources for LGBTQ plus young people that could be accessed online. That's so cool." Or hearing after talking with a group of sixth graders that one of them after our conversation did go to their social worker and say, "Hey, I'm worried about my peer." On one hand I have dreams about the big successes that we're going to see that the more information that we get out there, that the bigger results that we're going to see, which is cool, awesome. But really that success for me is when we hear about that individual, when we can touch that individual person in such a positive way, either connecting them with a new resource, keeping them from feeling isolated, empowering them to speak up and use their voice that they have, that's so powerful. That's what success is for me.

39.segment_words: That's what success is for me.
39.linked_words: what does success look like for you in relation to your work?

41.words: I would echo all of that and just add that we hear from staff that take our trainings also, they'll let us know, "Hey, we use that action plan that we learn from you." And that's really heartwarming to hear.

So for me, the success tends to, what I see, especially at the end of a quarter, the number of people that we're reaching with our trainings. So all of those staff members that we're teaching around the state of Maine, we're talking to, those staff members then are going on they're with their students every day. And just the impact of that in those building conversations. That feels like success to me, seeing how the information is spreading across the state.

40.segment_words: That feels like success to me, seeing how the information is spreading across the state.

43.words: Our next question is what are local trends in Maine or larger trends that impact us in Maine that might really transform what's expected of youth mental health organizations and providers in the coming decades? And do you expect other factors to play a role in changing the mental health, but specifically youth mental health industry?

44.words: I'm definitely going to wait for that one in the chat.

45.words: Yep. That was a much longer one.

44.segment_words: That was a much longer one.
44.linked_words: I'm definitely going to wait for that one in the chat.

46.words: In terms of local trends in Maine, we just recently got the Maine integrated youth health survey data from fall of 2021, released by the Maine CDC. To be totally honest, I have not yet had the opportunity to meaningfully dig into that. We have another survey for that coming up in spring of 2023. And between those two pieces, I think that's going to be very telling for us on where our young people are at. With the pandemic and the light that has been on mental health, I feel like there was a really big opportunity for positive change to happen. And as people have re-acclimated in, whether we call this the ongoing pandemic, post pandemic or whatever language it is that each person is using these days, I feel like as we've started to return to the sense of "normal", we're starting to see a pullback from understanding of youth mental health already, unfortunately. I think that the drive is there for more people to have that knowledge, awareness, and desire to do better. But I'm starting to see systems pulling back and trying to refocus on two things that were more traditionally a focus like with schools being pulled back to focusing solely on their standards. Whereas previously, maybe the administration would have supported more education around mental health for their staff. And unfortunately as a state, as a whole New England area as probably a whole country, we don't have a mental health system that is super functional yet. And I think that, that's something that is on a positive track or I'm hopeful that it is. But with the way that our system is set up right now, it is very reactive and we don't have enough providers. And the ones that we do have are working their hardest in doing their absolute best. And I am so grateful to them. But we look around the state and we see wait lists that are out of control. I hear about folks that have been on waiting lists for over a year for some services. And it's not that anyone's doing anything wrong, there's just not enough. And I think that how we move forward from this space right now is going to be very telling for what things are going to look like over the next couple decades. We're in a position to have legislature reevaluate where reimbursement rates are for Medicaid across the state. For insurance companies, on what kind of responsibility they have to serving people with mental health needs. How accessible that can be to people is unfortunately tied to financial status. If people don't have insurance or don't have access to Medicaid, that's not a feasible option for folks to be accessing ongoing professional support more often than not. And even those that do have access to those insurance coverage is not always ideal. And people are limited by having to have a specific diagnosis, often, diagnosis often that would provide them a prepackaged treatment plan often, it feels like. And again, that's not on the providers, I see that as an insurance problem that is directly impacting the care for not only our young people, but people at large. And I think that as we see this younger generation come up to voting age and being able to be more civically involved, I am hopeful that we're going to see some larger systemic changes that's going to impact really everyone's access to mental health services supports and the way that we view mental health, to be able to have it as an ongoing, open, honest conversation. Not this thing that gets swept back under the rug because we've returned to what we believe to be normalcy. So I'm always optimistic that we're headed in a better direction, but also realistic in that our system is not perfect. The individuals that are in it are trying and working their best, and I appreciate that to no end, but we always have room for growth and improvement.

43.segment_words: In terms of local trends in Maine, we just recently got the Maine integrated youth health survey data from fall of 2021, released by the Maine CDC. To be totally honest, I have not yet had the opportunity to meaningfully dig into that. We have another survey for that coming up in spring of 2023. And between those two pieces, I think that's going to be very telling for us on where our young people are at.
43.linked_words: Our next question is what are local trends in Maine

47.words: I would agree that I think the biggest trend that I'm seeing that's having an impact would be the access to resources in that Maine does not have the resources necessarily to meet the needs in the way that we would like to see those wait lists can be incredibly discouraging to people who are trying to get help. It could cause them to feel like they're being rejected even though that's not really what's happening. So those things can butt heads in ways that are not what we want to be seeing, but hopefully there will be things in place in the future that might mitigate some of those issues with resources that we have in our system at the moment. And then to add on to another thing that I see, other factors playing roles in youth mental health is the conversations that youth are seeing on the political national level. It has a very big impact, and particularly in this moment, thinking about like the LGBTQ community. Consistently, studies have shown over the years that they are disproportionately affected at higher rates where they're experiencing depression and they're having suicidal thoughts more often. I believe that the rates in the MHSS data that came out recently is that for LGBTQ individuals, it's around 40%. That shifts depending on which group we're looking at. But 40% I think is the lowest number of those groups. And so when we're then seeing conversations on a national level where there's pushback against having conversations in schools, then that's affecting those youth because it's affecting their safety at school, which should be a safe place for them. So that's just one example I think of many that we could pull out, but that is one factor that immediately came to mind for me.

43.segment_words: the biggest trend that I'm seeing that's having an impact would be the access to resources in that Maine does not have the resources necessarily to meet the needs

50.words: Yes. I think that people as a whole definitely value that. I think that being the individual working in the field, it can feel like systemically that you are not valued. And I think that's where the notion of boundaries and self care come into practice so much or the necessity of that because the work that people are doing, whether it be on a systems level, on a direct service level, what you're doing matters. And the people that you are engaging with see that and know that and connect with that, even though the amount of paperwork probably grows on a weekly basis, the insurance reimbursement things are not going to treat you like you matter. The news is probably not going to treat you like you matter. All of these big pieces that we see floating around, having opinions on things don't necessarily show that care and support, but the individuals, the actual community being served absolutely, completely valued, appreciated, and should be openly celebrated.

51.words: We got a thumbs up from Libby. Our next question. Oh, okay. Yeah, plenty of time. What ideas do you have for youth mental health organizations in schools and other learning environments? Let me rephrase that. What ideas do you have for how youth mental health organizations can work more fruitfully together with schools and other learning environments?

49.linked_words: do you feel like pursuing a career in mental health and specifically youth mental health is valued in Maine and in your communities?

52.words: More. More agencies, more providers, more resources to be able to offer to the schools. But these schools need more time, more funding, more teachers, more paraprofessionals, and it feels like both systems are in crisis mode in their own right. And trying to get that collaboration and prevention work going together when people are just trying to get through the day to make it through makes that really difficult. And so I think that when we have administrations in school and when we have teachers and professionals and other staff that are at schools that are wanting to not just get through but feel interested in learning more, when they feel supported in learning more. So when the messaging is coming down from them or from their powers that be, that it is a strength to learn more, to be an updated kind of support for the young people, not just the messaging of get through the day, we'll make it to tomorrow. That can make a huge difference in the partnerships.

51.segment_words: And so I think that when we have administrations in school and when we have teachers and professionals and other staff that are at schools that are wanting to not just get through but feel interested in learning more, when they feel supported in learning more. So when the messaging is coming down from them or from their powers that be, that it is a strength to learn more, to be an updated kind of support for the young people, not just the messaging of get through the day, we'll make it to tomorrow. That can make a huge difference in the partnerships.
51.linked_words: What ideas do you have for how youth mental health organizations can work more fruitfully together with schools and other learning environments?

53.words: We have a wonderful upstream suicide prevention program that we're working to get into as many Maine schools as possible. Right now it's really strength based and looking to the strengths that you have available to you to help work through life ups and downs, everyday stressors that are showing up for you. And we've found that schools are really excited about this program and want to be super invested. However, the lack of subs, the lack of time to be able to be away from the classroom, to be trained in this program and feeling like one more thing added to their plate has really made them hesitant to bring the program to schools. And so as Kristel said, I think more was a great way to sum that up. More time, more subs, more resources, more support so that they are able to connect and have these programs that they want to have, but the access accessibility is not right there for them to be able to get these programs going.

52.segment_words: And so as Kristel said, I think more was a great way to sum that up. More time, more subs, more resources, more support so that they are able to connect and have these programs that they want to have, but the access accessibility is not right there for them to be able to get these programs going.

55.words: Thinking about this one, it is such a big question, and I think one thing that's coming to mind maybe is finding ways to use our technology to be able to connect across communities, to bring people together more. And we've done a lot over the pandemic to build our technology usage, I think locally. But there's potential with the way technology has grown over the years, that there could be positive ways that it could be used to connect people. But I think a lot of the conversation around technology still is that focus on, Oh, but it could be this bad thing, or, Oh, it is this bad thing. Whereas I'd love to see some shift in conversation too, there are concerns with technology, but there are so many positive things. If we can find a way to look at those, reach those and mitigate some of those risks that people are always concerned about.

51.segment_words: it is such a big question, and I think one thing that's coming to mind maybe is finding ways to use our technology to be able to connect across communities, to bring people together more. 53.segment_words: Thinking about this one, it is such a big question, and I think one thing that's coming to mind maybe is finding ways to use our technology to be able to connect across communities, to bring people together more.
53.linked_words: More time, more subs, more resources, more support so that they are able to connect and have these programs that they want to have, but the access accessibility is not right there for them to be able to get these programs going.

59.words: As an aside with the technology piece, this has been such a great opportunity these last couple of years to be able to see people have the opportunity to use technology for their benefit of learning more and engaging in different ways. We all can appreciate that we were all headed in this direction anyways to be able to access online learning. But having that speed up of things was incredible in so many ways. Terrible that it came about the way that it did. But I'm glad that we now have been able to see trainings that we would've previously held in one community doing a gatekeeper training in northern Maine. We would have one population that would be at that training, whereas now if we hold something virtually, we can get such a more robust group together. We can have people that are working in schools in southern Maine, northern Maine, eastern Maine, western Maine, and there is so much similarity, but also such different perspectives that come together that way that really allow for some creative thought into how we're navigating all of the things in schools these days. And it's really great to see that different learning styles are being acknowledged in adults, finally. So to be able to see that shorter learning blocks are super effective, so by people having noticed that in adults, that's filtering down to acknowledging that our young people definitely have different learning styles and that it's not a bad thing, that we find what works for an individual and help them be successful with that. That's not making things "too easy for them". It's about helping them be successful and be the best version of themselves they can be.

55.segment_words: As an aside with the technology piece, this has been such a great opportunity these last couple of years to be able to see people have the opportunity to use technology for their benefit of learning more and engaging in different ways.
55.linked_words: to bring people together more. And we've done a lot over the pandemic to build our technology usage, I think locally. But there's potential with the way technology has grown over the years, that there could be positive ways that it could be used to connect people.

60.words: Yeah. Which is hugely, of course going to impact in turn their mental health. Our next question is a little bit more broad. What do you see as some of the most important experiences, skills, and capacities for youth to gain before adulthood in order for them to thrive and succeed in your communities in Maine specifically in the next few decades?

59.segment_words: Yeah. Which is hugely, of course going to impact in turn their mental health.
59.linked_words: It's about helping them be successful and be the best version of themselves they can be.

61.words: I think connection and willingness to explore help seeking behaviors. I think that when we have young people that have been shown that they can rely on the adults in their lives and that their peers have been a positive support, that shows them that they have community and that it's okay to ask for help and that doesn't make them weak or less than, but rather can shift that into being a strength to be able to have our young people not feel that they have to carry the weight of the world on their own, but rather it's a shared process. That we want them to come together as community and just be open to help. Offer help when you can provide it and be willing to accept it when someone's offering it.

60.segment_words: I think connection and willingness to explore help seeking behaviors. I think that when we have young people that have been shown that they can rely on the adults in their lives and that their peers have been a positive support, that shows them that they have community and that it's okay to ask for help and that doesn't make them weak or less than, but rather can shift that into being a strength to be able to have our young people not feel that they have to carry the weight of the world on their own, but rather it's a shared process.
60.linked_words: What do you see as some of the most important experiences, skills, and capacities for youth to gain before adulthood in order for them to thrive and succeed in your communities in Maine specifically in the next few decades?

62.words: This sounds simple, but healthy emotional regulation I think is a very important thing. I see in my generation and me personally did not have a high importance around that. And we're seeing it a lot more with younger individuals. And I think it's so important. It helps with communication, it helps with resiliency. Just overall, it's going to help going into adulthood and navigating stressors that are going to show up naturally. So I think healthy emotional regulation is a great thing that will help into adulthood.

60.segment_words: This sounds simple, but healthy emotional regulation I think is a very important thing.
60.linked_words: What do you see as some of the most important experiences, skills, and capacities for youth to gain before adulthood in order for them to thrive and succeed in your communities in Maine specifically in the next few decades?

61.segment_words: It helps with communication, it helps with resiliency.
61.linked_words: That we want them to come together as community and just be open to help.

63.words: This is the first thing that came to mind for me is actually quite different. Home economics, the programs were completely gutted. So when I was in high school, there were no home economics courses. We were not, that traditional students learning how to cook, learning how to do basic things to take care of themselves as adults. The financial literacy course in my school, the culture around it was the course for people who didn't know how to do math, which is completely wild to me because it was how do you write a check? How do you do your taxes? It was such important things. And then so kids are turning 18 and they're expected to take care of themselves in the world, which is an incredibly stressful experience because they're not being taught those basic foundational skills. Which I think kind of echoes back to what Kristel said at the very start of this, that food, starting with something like food and then building up. To be able to start with teaching our kids how they need to take care of themselves without focusing on where are they going professionally, where are they going academically first. I think there's been a huge priority on academic achievement and professional achievement with that has thrown some of those basic self-care things to the side a bit. And I'd love to see those traditional things come back.

61.segment_words: Which I think kind of echoes back to what Kristel said at the very start of this, that food, starting with something like food and then building up.
61.linked_words: I think connection and willingness to explore help seeking behaviors.

62.segment_words: And I'd love to see those traditional things come back.
62.linked_words: So I think healthy emotional regulation is a great thing that will help into adulthood.

64.words: I'd definitely agree with that. And also there's this assumption around our young people that you need to treat them like children, just treat them. They don't know anything through their 18th birthday. And then we hoist them forward and say, "Well, why didn't you know how to do that?" And so there needs to be this bridge of encouraging young people to be able to be a part of conversations and holding that space for them to be a part of decision making so that there's more things happening with them than at them. And so that transition to adulthood is going to be a whole lot smoother if the first time that they are making education decisions is not when they're a thousand miles away from home for the first time, trying to pick a college degree that's going to cost them an arm and a leg for the rest of their life. Thank you student loans.

63.segment_words: And also there's this assumption around our young people that you need to treat them like children, just treat them. They don't know anything through their 18th birthday. And then we hoist them forward and say, "Well, why didn't you know how to do that?"
63.linked_words: And then so kids are turning 18 and they're expected to take care of themselves in the world, which is an incredibly stressful experience because they're not being taught those basic foundational skills.

65.words: Yeah. Yeah. So our last question is, is there one thing that you want legislators, state or district level education leaders to know relating to the conversation we had today or something that you are doing thinking about in your work in mental health?

64.segment_words: relating to the conversation we had today
64.linked_words: there needs to be this bridge of encouraging young people to be able to be a part of conversations and holding that space for them to be a part of decision making

66.words: We need to be able to have the space and room to be able to help our young people as whole people, not as checklists, not as standards meeting, not as whatever other procedure might be in place. We need to be able to give our parents, caregivers, teachers, paraprofessionals, every other individual that is connecting with our young people to give them as much of the tools and resources and time in space to help our young people. To stop putting this culture of busy on everyone. To be able to slow things down some so that an individual can be seen as a whole person, not just a student that happens to be in a math class today, or a difficult teenager that works in the grocery store that's bothering you that day, but rather as whole people with whole lives and experiences that are going to need different supports in different ways at different times.

64.segment_words: We need to be able to have the space and room to be able to help our young people as whole people, not as checklists, not as standards meeting, not as whatever other procedure might be in place.
64.linked_words: And so there needs to be this bridge of encouraging young people to be able to be a part of conversations and holding that space for them to be a part of decision making so that there's more things happening with them than at them.

65.segment_words: We need to be able to have the space and room to be able to help our young people as whole people, not as checklists, not as standards meeting, not as whatever other procedure might be in place.
65.linked_words: is there one thing that you want legislators, state or district level education leaders to know relating to the conversation we had today or something that you are doing thinking about in your work in mental health?

67.words: And that we're partners in this. We all want the best for the young people in Maine. And part of that is, as I mentioned earlier, all of us being a piece of the puzzle that helps support them. We want young people to know that if you're struggling with your mental health, there are resources out there. There are things you can look to. And so we want to partner with all schools and be there to help support them and the young people. So just thinking of us as partners to support young people is really important.

64.segment_words: So just thinking of us as partners to support young people is really important.
64.linked_words: And so there needs to be this bridge of encouraging young people to be able to be a part of conversations and holding that space for them to be a part of decision making so that there's more things happening with them than at them.

66.segment_words: So just thinking of us as partners to support young people is really important.
66.linked_words: We need to be able to give our parents, caregivers, teachers, paraprofessionals, every other individual that is connecting with our young people to give them as much of the tools and resources and time in space to help our young people.

61.segment_words: So just thinking of us as partners to support young people is really important.
61.linked_words: it's a shared process. That we want them to come together as community and just be open to help.

68.words: And I would agree completely with both Kristel and Libby on that. And I think I would add, just listen to the youth. If there's something going on in the school culturally or there's a policy and students are saying they don't like it or they'd love to see a change, they want to add something into the school, some kind of program to make things better, listen to them and talk with them. Meet them on their level and have a conversation. See what you can do to help them make it happen or tell them in a way that makes sense to them, why it might not be able to. Just respect them, respect them as people, and not look at them as children because they are more capable than sometimes they're given credit for.

66.segment_words: Just respect them, respect them as people, and not look at them as children because they are more capable than sometimes they're given credit for.
66.linked_words: an individual can be seen as a whole person, not just a student that happens to be in a math class today, or a difficult teenager that works in the grocery store that's bothering you that day, but rather as whole people with whole lives and experiences

67.segment_words: And I would agree completely with both Kristel and Libby on that. And I think I would add, just listen to the youth.
67.linked_words: We all want the best for the young people in Maine. And part of that is, as I mentioned earlier, all of us being a piece of the puzzle that helps support them.

69.words: Absolutely. As a quick add-on to that, I think of recently, Libby and I met with a group of students that were expressing some frustrations with the culture at their school that there was a culture of physical violence at this school and they were worried about how the school was responding or not responding. And they took it upon themself to put together these flyers, posters that they wanted to put up around the school to encourage communication. And it was done in such a respectful manner. It was very accessible in the way that they were designed. It was wonderful to see a young person take it upon themselves to do something like that, to essentially make an action plan and want to follow through on it. The difficulty that we saw in that moment was this young person came to the school so excited to be able to hopefully do something about this problem that they're seeing. And instead of being met with excitement or, Wow, great job with that. Let's see how to integrate that. It almost felt dismissive. And that's where a lot of our problems are stemming out of. We have adults that are working with young people that got into it for all of the right reasons, and their heart has been there through everything, but they have been stretched so thin, and they have had to give everything and have more asked of them on an ongoing basis that they don't always have enough left in them to be able to make that connection, to be able to be that resource and support. So we need to build out these systems in a meaningful way that makes it sustainable, that makes it so these people that care and want to help our young people can do that work. And that is a huge shift that we need to make.

And they took it upon themself to put together these flyers, posters that they wanted to put up around the school to encourage communication. And it was done in such a respectful manner. It was very accessible in the way that they were designed. It was wonderful to see a young person take it upon themselves to do something like that, to essentially make an action plan and want to follow through on it.
68.linked_words: If there's something going on in the school culturally or there's a policy and students are saying they don't like it or they'd love to see a change, they want to add something into the school, some kind of program to make things better, listen to them and talk with them. Meet them on their level and have a conversation. See what you can do to help them make it happen or tell them in a way that makes sense to them, why it might not be able to.

70.words: Yeah. That was great. Thank you all for sharing your perspectives and experiences. You're one of the more niche groups that we've talked with because we haven't met with anyone who's working in youth mental health. And it felt really important that we got to talk with you guys because that's such a huge part of how our kids are going to do in school. And then when they go out into our communities when they're 18, what's going to happen? How are they going to thrive or not thrive? And so yeah, I'm really grateful that you guys took the time to do this and shared everything that you shared today. Thank you so much.

65.segment_words: I’m really grateful that you guys took the time to do this and shared everything that you shared today.
65.linked_words: Thank you all for sharing your perspectives and experiences.

71.words: Thank you so much for having us. It's been wonderful to be a part of this conversation and I know that I'm excited to see how these pieces come out and learn some other great things about what's going on in Maine. I know that we are a small state, but there is so much going on around us that we don't always know what it is. So what a great
